Mark Farrell

Association Schemes from Graphs

May 22, 2017

In this post, I would like to establish some examples of families of commutative association schemes arising from distance-regular graphs and sets of conjugacy class digraphs of finite groups.

Firstly, suppose that is a distance-regular graph. Let denote the vertex set of , and denote a set of distance matrices for . Additionally, define for all and all . Now, select any particular . Then for any :

  1. [ since is a simple graph ].

  2. [ since is distance-regular ].

  3. [ letting denote the standard inner product on ,

    and denote the representative vector of in for all ].

[ since and are arbitrary, in addition to the facts that , , and for all by construction ].

It then follows in general that every distance-regular graph gives rise to a commutative association scheme in this way, since in this context is arbitrary.

Secondly, suppose now that is a finite group. Let denote the identity element of , denote the set of conjugacy classes of , and denote the of set adjacency matrices of the set of conjugacy class digraphs of relative a certain ordering of the elements of and . Additionally, define for all and all , letting denote the -th conjugacy class of for all . Then for any particular and any :

  1. Define

    It is apparent that and are bijections.

  2. Select any .

    It follows from 1. that for all .

Now, for all and all define:

  • and

    .

Then for any particular :

  • Select any .

Next, observe that:

  • since .

  • since every element of belongs to exactly one conjugacy class of .

  • for all

    since for all

    there is a such that if and only if

    for all .

  • for some and all ,

    following from the previous point.

It then follows in general that the set of conjugacy classes of every finite group gives rise to a commutative association scheme in this way, since in this context is arbitrary.

In conclusion, it is indeed the case that distance-regular graphs and sets of conjugacy classes of finite groups give rise to commutative assocation schemes in the ways presented in this posted. It may be useful to note that it essentially follows that every distance-regular graph is walk-regular from the facts that the distance matrices of a distance-regular graph are simultaneously diagonalizable, the number of distinct eigenvalues of distance-regular graph is equal to one more than its diameter, in addition to the fact that distance-regular graphs give rise to commutative association schemes. Also, the fact that there are sets of projections onto the generalized eigenspaces of the adjacency matrices of the set of conjugacy class digraphs that form bases for the Bose-Mosner algebra of the conjugacy class scheme of a finite group is arguably useful for finding general expressions for the spectra of conjugacy class digraphs of finite groups; I hope to expand on this point in detail in a future post. Lastly, it may also be worth noting that there are arguably useful examples of families of association schemes arising from complex commutants of sets of permutation matrices as well as sets of orbits of certain actions on finite groups; however, these families of association schemes are not necessarily commutative and so my intent is to perhaps talk about them in a separate post in the future as well.
